awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Control of Arsenic in Groundwater by Microbial Arsenate Reduction
awd_abstract_narration:
Title:	Microbial Arsenate Reduction Control on Arsenic in Groundwater
Abstract   The proposed research addresses natural occurrences of elevated arsenic in aquifers, a compelling public health hazard to a large population in both the United States and areas around the world. We focus on the role of microorganisms in controlling arsenic concentrations in aquifers, particularly at low values but still above the drinking water standards. The proposed study will determine quantitatively the role of microbial arsenate reduction in the bedrock aquifer in the Southern Willamette Basin, Oregon, USA. Arsenic occurs naturally in the aquifer at concentrations as high as 2000 parts per billion (ppb). This aquifer serves as a model for studying arsenic contamination in aquifers of felsic volcanic rocks and related alluvial sediments. We will conduct field biostimulation experiments and biogeochemical reactive transport modeling to test the hypothesis that microbial arsenate reduction controls significantly arsenic attenuation and mobilization in anoxic aquifers. Results of this study will pinpoint quantitatively the significance of different microbial functional groups in regulating arsenic concentrations in the aquifer. The theoretical component of this study will advance biogeochemical reaction modeling that couples microbial metabolisms with geochemical reactions. Results of this study will also provide critical information concerning groundwater microbiology for government agencies in designing effective strategies and regulations for groundwater resource management, monitoring, and protection. We will collaborate with science instructors at high schools near the field site to develop a replicable and sustainable classroom lesson on arsenic into their science curriculum. The teaching portfolio of the arsenic lesson will be distributed to all Oregon K-12 educators to help Oregon public schools better prepared for a new requirement of a science class with laboratory experience by the Oregon State Board of Education.

por.por_cntn:
Arsenic (As) is a common geogenic and anthropogenic contaminant, and is ubiquitous in natural environments. The presence of arsenic in groundwater poses a health threat to the populations in many regions of the world, including Southeast Asia and many states of USA. Arsenic is redox sensitive, and occurs in groundwater mainly as arsenite and arsenate and to a lesser extent as monomethylarsonate and dimethylarsinate. A fundamental challenge to predicting the occurrence of arsenic in groundwater is the lack of knowledge of microbial transformation of arsenic among different arsenicals under in situ aquifer conditions.

We examined how microbial redox metabolisms and arsenic methylation control arsenic speciation and occurrence in the primary bedrock aquifer in the southern Willamette Basin, Oregon, USA. The aquifer is a representative volcanic aquifer that consists of low-permeability, late Eocene to Oligocene felsic volcanic sandstone, tuff, and silicic ash.

In a series of field and laboratory studies, we found that in the bedrock aquifer, key microbial processes included microbial respiration of ferric iron, sulfate, and arsenate and methanogenesis. Ferric iron respiration released arsenic into groundwater by dissolving ferric minerals, arsenate respiration converted arsenate to arsenite, and sulfate respiration produced sulfide. Adding ethanol into the aquifer stimulated these metabolisms. Although ferric respiration released arsenic from ferric minerals, sulfate and arsenate respiration maintained relatively low arsenic in groundwater by forming arsenic sulfide minerals.

 

Perhaps, our most significant finding is that inorganic arsenic in the groundwater is methylated at a rate of 0.1% of total arsenic per day, a value that is comparable to those in surface environments. Biomethylation generates a series of methylarsenicals, which differ from inorganic arsenic in their physical, chemical, and physiological properties.  This process has been largely neglected in the study of groundwater arsenic contamination. Our study showed that arsenic biomethylation is a potentially significant microbial process that can directly impact the occurrence, fate, and toxicity of arsenic in the bedrock aquifer. 

 

Our results point to a potential role of aquifer prokaryotes in global arsenic cycling, that is they link arsenic cycle in aquifers to that in surface environments. Current models portray two spatially separate cycles: a cycle in surface environments through inorganic and organic arsenicals, and a subsurface cycle between arsenate and arsenite in aquifers. Aquifer prokaryotes may also convert inorganic arsenic to volatile methylarsines, which then diffuse along unsaturated fractures and through sediments and soils to the surface environment. Without biomethylation, the link between the two cycles is likely limited because of limited zones where groundwater recharges and discharges. 

Our results also suggest a novel remediation approach for arsenic-contaminated groundwater. By adding ethanol and other electron donors into aquifers, we can stimulate biomethylation, and speed up the conversion of inorganic arsenic to methylarsines. Methylarsines can then be removed from groundwater by sparging and collected on site for further treatment.

 

The project provided training and professional opportunities for students at different levels, from K-12 to graduate students. We developed a two-hour classroom activity on groundwater arsenic contamination for highschool science class. Highschool students learn water quality and groundwater arsenic contamination by hands-on chemical analysis using Hach EZ Arsenic Test Kit, and by data analysis and interpretation.
